Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p: For the convenience of families and others, a large portion of each ship's accommodation has been reserved for Egypt, so that Berths can be definitely engaged at once, as if the voyage were commencing at Port Said. Plans can be seen at the Offices of the Company's Agents.

The through Steamers for Marseilles and London are intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Tuesday for the present except the MONGOLIA, which is taking passengers to the Anglo-French Naval Review, and will not wait at Port-Said on 24/25 July. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.
The Brindisi Express Steamers leave Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before. The Fare remains as usual.
For all further information apply to the Company's Agents,
Messrs. THOS. COOK & SON (Egypt) Ltd. CAIRO.
GEORGE ROYLE, Esq. PORT-SAID.
Messrs. HABELDEN & Co. ALEXANDRIA.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez fortnightly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for JEDDAH, SUAKIN, MASSOWAH, HODBIDAH, and ADEN ; and in the intervening weeks for PORT SUDAN and SUAKIN direct. Calls will be made at TOR (for Mount Sinai) as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company's Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

div.head: REMARKS.
div.p: The weather yesterday was cool, and as the day advanced the wind rosek making the night fairly cold. To-day opens dull and raw, with light gales from S.W. and a falling barometer. Indications point to rain during the day.

div.head: THE EXTERMINATION OF MOSQUITOES.
div.p: How true it is that there is nothing new under the sun! It has been pointed out that the use of nets against mosquitoes in Egypt is spoken of in Herodotus. But a correspondent has sent us an extract from the writings of Lucian of Samonata, a contemporary of Trojan, which clearly shows that even the use of oil as a preventative of the accumulation of insects was known. Speaking of the fly, he says, "It is in man's company as long as it lives, and takes the freedom to taste of all his food-oil only excepted, because it is poison to him." The fable tells us that the fly was originally a very beautiful but very loquacious woman, a perpetual tattler and a singer into the bargain. She was rival to the Moon in her love with Endymion; and the Moon, being in a rage with her one day, turned her into a fly. For this reason she still seems to envy everybody's sleep, especially the tender and young, retaining in her memory the sleep of Endymion. Her bites and thirst for blood (evidently a reference to the mosquito) proceed not from cruelty, but humanity and love. Lucian also mentions that Tragedy mentions this fly-
"That the fly may be with dreadful slaughter filled, She flies with wondrous force upon the body, And armed warriors fear her little dart."

Lucian evidently classes the mosquito as a fly, as he speaks of it inflicting a wound by its bite, not only in man's skin, but in that of an ox and a horse. There is also a reference to the proboscis making an incision in the wrinkles of an elephant's trunk.

The fact that oil was known to the ancients as being poisonous to flies makes one wonder why it is only comparatively recently that this fact has been put to practical use. We have little doubt but that, as it has been possible to rid lamailia of the mosquito and its attendant evils, so in the event of an honest endeavor being made to cope with the breeding of mosquitoes in any other place, we will find that pari person there will be a great decrease in the number of flies and other insects.

We have strongly advocated the wholesale destruction of mosquitoes in our reports, having in mind the experiences of other towns, such as New Orleans, which was recently devastated with yellow fever. That we are not at present in any danger is entirely due to the fact that no one of yellow fever has ever reached Egypt. Should it ever make its appearance in this country, where we have its carrier, the mosquito, in such numbers, Egypt may be devastated with a plague equal in the severity of its consequences to the visualization of the time of Moses.

div.head: Legislative Council.
div.p: The meeting called for Thursday last has been postponed until the 15th inst.

div.head: "La Margherita."
div.p: The Margherita Society is giving a masked ball at the Eden Theatre this evening, commencing at 9 o'clock.

div.head: Cairo Ghaffirs.
div.p: 11 of the Cairo ghaffirs have been dismissed and the pay of the others increased from P.T. 120 to P.T. 150.

div.head: Alexandria Arenolith Co.
div.p: This new company has been formed for the transport of stones. It has received the Khedivial authorisation.

div.head: A New Company.
div.p: The Khedivial decree, authorising the creation of the "Societe d'Entreprise- Immobilibres et de Travanx," has been signed.

div.head: Egypt and Bulgaria.
div.p: The preliminary negotiations in regard to a commercial convention between Egypt and Bulgaria are proceeding satisfactorily.

div.head: Slave Trade.
div.p: Two new English inspectors are to be appointed to the Repression of the Slave Trade Department at salaries of L.E. 500 and L.E. 700 respectively.

div.head: Accident to an Official.
div.p: While going round Ghezireh in his dogcart, Mr. Mitchell Innes was thrown out owing to his vehicle colliding with another. The Under- Secretary of State at the Ministry of Finance was not much injured but only a little bruised.

div.head: Coal Imports.
div.p: The imports of coal during January amounted to 71,655 tons, as compared with 32,338 tons in the same month of last year. Last month Wales sent 45,121 tons, Newcastle 11,536, the Scotch districts 2,726 and Yorkshire 11 522.

div.head: Greek Schools.
div.p: Rostovitz Bey and M. Gianaclis, President and Vice-President of the Greek Community at Cairo, have announced that they will give L.E. 20,000 for the purchase of a large plot of land by Shoubra Caracol on which schools for Greek children will be built.

div.head: New Official Posts.
div.p: The Council of Ministers has confirmed the appointment of a second engineer in the Ports and Lighthouses Administration and of a clerk in the Mixed Tribunals with salaries at the rate of from L.E. 192 to L.E. 240 for the former and L.E. 192 to L.E. 288 for the latter per annum.

div.head: American Mission.
div.p: It is expected that the Rev. Dr. Pugh, who has done a great deal of evangelistic work in Wales and in other parts of the world, will deliver an address at the American Mission church, Cairo, to-morrow evening at six o'clock. It is hoped that many will avail themselves of the opportunity to hear him. All are cordially invited.

div.head: Professor Petrie's Lectures.
div.p: The dates for these interesting lectures are fixed for the 19th and 26th inst. and on March 5 and 12. They will be delivered at the Continental Hotel and will be illustrated by lantern slides. Each lecture will commence at 5 p.m. The subjects are as follows : 1. The Egyptians in Sinai ; 2. Egyptian Art. Greek Period ; 3. Egyptian Art. Middle Period; 4, Egyptian Art. Early Period.

div.head: To-morrow's Services.
div.p: To morrow the preacher at St. Mark's at the 11 a.m. service will be the Venerable Archdeacon Potter, M. A., Archdeacon of the Anglican Church in Cyprus. In the evening, at 6.30, the Archdeacon will preach at All Saints'. Ramleh. At both services the collection will be given ti the "Church of England Cyprus Fund," which the Archdeacon represents. The anthem at St. Mark's at 11 a.m. and 4.15 p.m. will be 'O taste and see" (Sir J. Goss), taken from Psalm XXXIV 8.10.

div.head: The Future of the Sudan.
div.p: The future of the Sudan presents itself under the happiest omen. The knowledge of the Arabic language is absolutely necessary to all those—military or civil—who wish to establish themselves in this new field of activity. To satisfy numerous demands the Berlitz Schools have arranged, according to the Berlitz principle, a short and very useful course of Arabic lessons. The pupils can thus learn, in a short time, all that is sufficient to know in that language. Alexandria, 26, Rue de l'EgliseCopte; Cairo l,Rue Kamel. [ADVT.].

div.head: NOTICE.
div.p: Commercial travellers, visiting Cairo, should arrange with the commercial Bureau for introductions to business firms. By doing so they will have greater facilities of introducing their goods, economising time, and avoiding worry.
The Commercial Bureau,
Opposite English Church House,
CAIRO.

div.p: Bulkeley (near Alexandria.)

Full Pension P.T. 50 a day. Visitors fron Cairo alight at Sidi-Gaber Station.

div.head: NEW SUDAN RAILWAY.
IMPORTANT CONFERENCES.
CHAWARBI PACHA'S SPEECH.
div.p: The Press correspondents dined with Slatin Pacha last night and were very pleasantly entertained. The members of the Legislative Council lunch with the Sirdar to-day. I hear that the last two days of Lord Cromer's stay here were occupied with a series of conferences in connection with Sudan problems, especially the land question. The Press correspondents visit the Sirdar before their departure to express thanks for the great kindness shown them during their stay The members of the Legislative Council lunch at the Palace, where a levee is to be held on Sunday.
(From our Special Correspondent).
Port Sudan, January 26.

The following is a translation of the speech delivered by Chawarbi Pacha, of the Legislative Council, on the occasion of the opening of the Nile-Red Sea Railway :— "Praise to the Lord of the worlds and prayer and peace be unto his faithful Prophet and unto all prophets and apostles. The Egyptian nation presents salaams and saltations to its sister-nation the Sudan and offers on this fortunate day congratulations on the inauguration of so important and netful a work—a token of civilisation and an omen of successful progress. You are aware, my brethren, that the region in which we celebrate this ceremony, like the other regions of the Sudan, was once a home of imposture and fanaticism and a source of disturbances and rebellions, and was for several years subject to the horrors of war, disease, and to many calamities, so that you would have been reduced to misery and would have indeed been utterly destroyed had it not been for the grace of God and the watchful care of H. H. the Khedive Abbas Pacha Helmy the Second and his Government, combined with the wisdom and valour of the British Empire and the skillful administration of that venerated chief, the renowned statesman who presides over this ceremony in the name of both the Egyptian and the British Governments. I refer to the Right Hon. the Earl of Cromer, His Britannic Majesty's Agent and Consul-General in the Nile Valley. The two Governments have combined to save you and your country from utter destruction. I only mention your past sufferings on an occasion of joy and congratulation in order to draw a comparison between your present and your past, and to thank God for His mercy on you and to thank your exalted rulers for the benefits they have already conferred upon you. "In consequence of the agreement between the Governments of H. H. the Khedive and of the British Empire, that rebellion was suppressed, its instigators and supporters were utterly an nihilated, a just and well organised Government was established in their place, and the banners of peace and prosperity which we now see flying were hoisted throughout your land This came to pass after the sacrifice of the lives of thousands of men from among us and our helpers and the expenditure of millions of pounds, which we have willingly and liberally offered in order to see you, as we see you to-day, happy and prosperous, assembled to celebrate the accomplishment of one of the greatest and most important of these works which are highly prized among the civilised nations of the world, the foundation of Fort Sudan and the extension of the railway between this port and Berber, an enterprise now achieved, which links the regions of the Sudan with the civilised world; in other words, it exchanges the products and fruits of the Sudan, formerly neglected and undervalued owing to the lack of adequate means of communication, with the special products of western civilisation, its numerous inventions, and the different commodities in which its markets trade. It will also facilitate and shorten the journey to the Hedjaz and the pilgrimage to Mecca. While this great work and other useful works which have a ready been completed in the Sudan, have been made possible by the care of H.H.'s Government and of the Government of Great Britain, yet we should not forget the high energy exhibited by that gallant commander Major General Sir Reginald Wingate, Sirdar of the Egyptian Army and Governor-General of the Sudan, who, together with his able assistants, and notably those who have helped in the construction of this railway—the inauguration of which you celebrate on this happy day—deserve our warmest admiration and thanks. If any nation in the world should take part in your public ceremonies and national rejoicings we Egyptians should be-that nation, we who consider your country and ours as twins, two bodies possessing one soul, each of which feels whatever affects the other. This is the reason that you see us here among you at this splendid ceremony to exchange our congratulations and to strengthen that, connection between the two countries which is due to the River Nile, which connects and flows through both and is almost the only source of their life and happiness. "It is natural for those in your condition, recently freed from tumults and insurrections, and now enjoying a period of peace and tranquillity, to deliberate on the prospects of their future. You will therefore permit me, my brothers, to give you a summary of the reforms achieved in our country so as to enable you to foretell your country's future. In 1881, at the beginning of the notorious end deplorable

rebellion in Egypt, the income of the Government amounted to L.E. 8,560,000. On September 15, 1882, the rebellion was suppressed and since that date the Egyptian Government has gradually improved in organisation and administration until it has reached a standard that is in itself a guarantee against relapse. Its financial position resembles that of the most civilised Governments and its income, as shown in the present year's Budget (1906), amounts to L.E. 13,500,000, i.e, about £5,000,000 more than in 1881, although several State taxes have either been reduced or wholly abolished. Meantime H.H. the Khedive's Government has expended millions of pounds to lighten the burden of the people and to avert the dangers that from time to time threatened the country, such as the cotton worm, the locusts, and the evil effects of too low or of too high a Nile. The Government has also during this period spent enormous sums on the opening of canals, the construction of dams and reservoirs, the establishment of justice, the enactment of laws, the facilitation of the means of communication throughout the country, on the organisation of the army, the consolidation of governmental authority in the interior, and on the protection of the frontier of both countries against any aggression or attack. In consequence of this, my brothers, the capitalist of Europe hastened to our land and numerous enterprises were undertaken and the sources of gain multiplied. The cultivator, the proprietor, the merchant, and the tradesman shared in the benefits of this movement. The prices of commodities have risen and the general wealth of the country has increased, while the financial and economic condition of the people has been improved to such a degree that they have lately made up in great part for their past losses. "This is, my brethren, the present state of affairs in Egypt which we hope to see you enjoy in your own country in the near future. We ask God to enable you to profit by the virtues and benefits of civilisation and to avoid its evils. Last of all we hope that we may again meet at similar ceremonies under the shadow of H. H. the Khedive, whom God perserve. Amen."
FRENCH HOMAGE.

In an article on the inauguration of the Nile-Red Sea railway the Parisian "Temps" gives a sketch of Sudan progress under the English and concludes with the remark, "On ns pent qne rendro hommage à cette magro'fi- qne victoire de la volontl et de la mdthode."

div.head: DEATH OF DISTINGUISHED OFFICER.
div.p: Lieut.-Colonel Richard Lewis Milne, D.S.O., who served in the Egyptian War and took part in the Battle of Tel el Kebir, died on the first instant.

Lieut.-Col. Milne was born on April 10, 1852, and entered the Army in 1873, but retired recently. He received his baptism of fire in the Afghan War of 1878-80, being mentioned in despatches. He took part in the march to Candahar, where he likewise gained mention in despatches, the medal with three clasps, and a bronze decoration. In the Egyptian War of 1882 he won the medal with clasp and the Khedive's star. He afterwards took part in the Burmah expedition, 1885-88 (despatches, D.S.O., medal with clasp) and served in South Africa from 1899-1902, acting as Assistant Press Censor in 19 0 (Queen's medal, three clasps; King's medal, two clasps; D.S.O.).

div.head: THE KHEDIVE.
div.p: H. H. the Khedive to-day visited the tombs of his Highness's forefathers, returning afterwards to Koubbeh Palace.

div.head: THE PILGRIMAGE.
div.p: A telegram from Mecca says that the population of Mecca just now, including the pilgrims, numbers 110,000. The health of everyone is perfect.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS.
div.p: The S.S. Sailor Prince, from Manchester, with passengers and general cargo, left Malta on Friday, and is due to arrive at Alexandria on Monday. The Ellerman S.S. Fabian sailed hence on Friday for Liverpool with a general cargo, including 4,143 bales cotton. The S.S. Carib Prince left Manchester on Friday, and is due at Alexandria, via Tunis and Malts, on 17th inst.

div.head: EGYPTIAN COTTON MILLS.
THE EXCISE DUTY.
FREE TRADE AND THE GOVERNMENT.
div.p: Among those who believe that the new Government at home will change the policy that has hitherto been followed in Egypt is the chairman of the Egyptian Cotton Mills. At the annual general meeting of that company, held in London last week, that gentleman declared that he was disposed to think "that with such a strong Free Trade Government in power," they ought to be successful in getting the obnoxious excise duty removed, if proper representations were now made. This point of view is rather amusing as the determination of the Egyptian Government to impose the excise duty in this case has been stated by Lord Cromer as being dictated from a Free Trade standpoint, and in his statement of the Government's case his lordship remarked that "to Free-traders the action taken by the Egyptian Government requires no defence. I fear that nothing I can say will be likely to convince confirmed Protectionists." The position taken up by the Government is that the abolition of the excise duty would encourage the growth of a protected cotton industry in Egypt, inasmuoh as Egyptian cotton now goes to Lancashire paying a one per cent. export duty, and is reimported in the form of yarn and piece goods, paying an eight per cent ad valorem import duty. The excise duty on the preducts of the Egyptian Cotton Mills was therefore enforced in the interests of Free Trade because it placed the home-made on precisely the same footing as the imported goods, in accordance with the precedent set by the Government of India. Lord Cromer supported this policy because, as he declared, "I do not consider that, in Egyptian interests, it would be at all desirable to imperil the considerable revenue derived from the customs duties on cotton goods by the creation of an industry which would very probably have had to depend mainly on Protection for its existence." We are afraid that it will not matter a jot whether the Government be Free Trade or Protectionist for there is little likelihood that the cotton mill policy in India or Egypt will be changed in order to permit of the mills of those countries competing with Lancashire without a handicap. The seventh annual general meeting of the Egyptian Cotton Mills (Limited) was held yesterday week at Winchester House, Mr. Giles Atherton, J. P., presiding. In moving the adaption of the report, the chairman said whereas the gross profit on manufacture at the mill the previous year was only £992, the accounts then presented for the year ended Sept 30 last showed a gross profit of £14,409. The year 1906 would be remembered as a phenomenal year in the history of the cotton trade, and if was a pity that the company was not in a position to share in that prosperity during the whole of the year. With, regard to the future he was glad to believe, that the prospects were very healthy, but although trade had been exceptionally good, they could hardly expect it to remain at that high-water mark. There was, however, every indication that the country was likely to enjoy a period of long prosperity. Were it not for the three important items of commissions, &c., excise duty, and interest, &c., the net profits would have been considerably more than £2,726. Regarding the excise duty, he was disposed to think that with such a strong Free Trade Government in power, if proper representations were now made, they ought to be successful in getting that obnoxious tax removed. In order to place the concern on a sound basis, he would suggest that the directors at once take steps to reduce the capital of the company to, say, one- half, or £80,000. and issue preference shares to the extent of £30 000. He was confident that had the undertaking received fair encouragement at the hands of the Egyptian Government, it would without doubt have shown excellent results. Mr. T. Stoker seconded the resolution, which was carried unanimously.

div.head: DUTY ON EGYPTIAN COTTON IN U.S.A.
div.p: Representative Clark of Florida, has introduced a bill into the Legislators which has been referred to the Committee on Ways and Means, providing for levying a duty on Egyptian and other long-staple cotton imported into the United States from foreign countries. The bill provides : That on and after the first day of October, 1906, there shall be levied, collected, and paid upon all Egyptian and other long staple cotton imported into the United States from foreign countries, in the lint, an import duty at the rate of 10 cents per pound, and upon all Egyptian and other long-staple cotton imported into the United States from foreign countries, in the seed, an import duty at the rate of 4 cents per pound.

div.head: PORT SAID NOTES.
NEWS FROM THE YEMEN.
DESPATCH OF REINFORCEMENTS.
div.p: The Sultan has ordered the immediate despatch of 10,000 troops for the relief of Faizi Pacha, who is reported to be hard pressed by the rebels in the Yemen. Arrangements are being made for the transport of these troops to Hodeideh.
Warships.

The first-class cruiser H.M.S. Kent passed through Port Said on January 29, en route for the Chinese Squadron. The French transport Cholon went through on the same date, en route for Haiphang, with 500 troops. When the Russian cruisers Oleg and Aurora were leaving, the officers and crew of the French transport gave the Russians a great send-off, shouting "Vive la Ratine," which cries were vociferously reciprocated by the Russians. Eli S. Diana is expected back in Port Said on February 6. The Minerva will return to Alexandria on the 9th.
Sport

The younger residents of Port Said are greatly indebted to the officers and crew of the warships for the encouragement they have given to the promotion of sport in the town. For the last two months there has been, on an average, three games of football a week. Owing to the success of the Rugby match between Port Said and the Diana, a match was played with the Minerva, resulting, however, in a defeat for Port Said by 8 points to nil. The latter gave a very creditable performance, considering that a few of the team had not played Rugby before. Gunnery, Wallace, Cox, and King, especially, gave a good exposition of the game. The Association match, Port Said v. Minerva, ended in a draw 2 goals each. Gunnery boo red both goals for Port Said. On Saturday afternoon the officers and crew of H. M. S. Minerva hold field sports in Port Said.
Hookey.

Hookey has become very popular here of late, for the introduction of which we have to thank the Diana and Minerva. It is pleasing to see some of the older sporting enthusiasts donning the jersey again. All this interest in sport angora well for the success of the new Sporting Club, which will be in fall swing next season
A Tragedy.

A tragedy which occurred here on Wednesday night about 10 o'clock caused a great sensation owing to the circumstances under which it occurred, A French working man named Senes, who lived with an Italian woman, attempted to kill his mistress by cutting her throat with the blade of a jointing plane. The couple were locked in their room when all of a sudden the neighbours heard piteous cries for help. They forced open the door and found the poor woman stretched out on the ground with her head almost severed from the body. The murderer managed to escape by another door, but he was caught and arrested almost immediately. The unfortunate victim was removed to hospital in a precarious condition, and little hopes are entertained of her recovery. The object of the crime is unknown.

div.head: ALL SAINTS' CHURCH, CAIRO.
FABRIC IN BAD CONDITION.
div.p: At a special meeting of the committee of All Saints' Church, Cairo, held recently at H.B.M.'s Agency, the Earl of Cromer in the chair, Lord Cromer said that the fabric of the church was in a very bad condition and called on Mr. B. Richmond to make a statement. Mr. Richmond reported that the foundations of the church were sound ; but that the wall of the north aisle was unsafe, and that the whole aisle must be rebuilt, and the structure strengthened in other ways. It was decided that the necessary works should be commenced at once and that the scraping of the interior should be begun at the earliest opportunity. It was decided not to enlarge the north aisle, but to rebuild on its present lines. It was farther determined to address an appeal to the English and American residents and visitors, and to solicit subscriptions. The east sum required for necessary repairs will be £500; and if the building is put in thorough repair more will be needed. Judge Tuck proposed that copies of the appeal, and collecting cards, should be placed in the peers on the ensuing Sunday. This suggestion was unanimously approved and acted on with good effect. During the past week and indeed every day since the Dean's first appeal in Church subscriptions have flowed in. A special list of subscribers to the Restoration Fund will be published. During the restoration it will be necessary to discontinue all week day services except the Holy Communion at 8.30 on Fridays and Saints' days, The Sunday services will be held us usual; the North aisle has been screened off, but the rest of the church can be used all through the restoration.

div.head: THE COTTON FIRE.
WORK OF SALVAGING BEGUN.
EXTENT OF DAMAGE
div.p: A meeting of all the agents of the insurance companies affected by the fire at the Press ex-Choremi was held yesterday afternoon at the offices of the Societe de Pressage et des Depots. M. Charruy, the manager of the company and agent for three English insurance companies affected, took the chair. He opened the proceedings with a detailed statement of the property. The meeting afterwards unanimously decided to confer the fullest powers on the chairman in regard to the disposal of the property not damaged by the fire and also in reference to going on with the work of the press at the earliest possible opportunity. This demonstration of confidence in the manager of the Pressage Company, as shown by the meeting, will greatly facilitate, matters, and it reflects credit on the agents of the insurance companies, as such promptness will tend to improve the salvage, which is a very important item under the circumstances. The companies have authorised the Societe de Pressage to draw twenty-five per cent. on the value insured, which is very liberal and puts the clients of the Pressage in a favourable position. The meeting next elected a committee of adjustment composed as follows: Messrs. Charroy, Percy Carver, Adolphe Stross, and Sevastopoulo. We learn that this committee subsequently appointed Mr. Charroy as their chairman. The salvage of the cotton began early this morning. The work was entrusted to Mr. Frank Haselden, who has had great experience of this class of work on similar occasions. Possibly the loss will be a little less than was expected as the salvage is somewhat more important than was originally thought, for a great many of the bales wen steam-pressed; and consequently the interior is not seriously damaged in many cases. Our criticism as to the faulty condition of the Alexandria Fire Brigade hose and the weak water projection are corroborated on all sides, and universal surprise is expressed at the Municipality having allowed the Fire Brigade's equipment to be in such a state.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL.
div.p: Lord Masham, whose death is announced in to-day's telegrams, was one of the most successful Yorkshiremen of his day and his inventions brought him a great fortune. He invented the compressed air brake and the wool carding machine, but the bulk of his success in life was due to his discovery of a system of turning waste products into plush. He was born in 1815 and created a Baron in 1891. He took his title from the town of Masham, which was chiefly his property. It was one of the attainted titles of the oldest family in Yorkshire, the Scropes.
Mazlonm Pacha, Finance Minister, is confined to his room with a slight indisposition.

The "Der Tag" of Berlin announced recently as probable the appointment of Baron Jenisch, German Consul-General at Cairo, to the post of Minister at Copenhagen. The news, however, which has appeared in all the local papers, is devoid of foundation in fact.

Sir Edward Grey's wife, who, according to to-day's telegrams, has had a most serious accident, is the daughter of Mr. S. F. Widdirgton, of Newton Halt, Northumberland. She married the Undersecretary of State for foreign Affairs in 1885. There are no children of the marriage.
Miss Cordelia Whiteside, the , miniature painter, has arrived in Cairo from London, and is staying at Rossmore House, Sharia el Madabegh.
The marriage of M. Gustave Cattaoni and Miss Regina Mosseri was celebrated with great splendour on Thursday afternoon in the Jewish Tabernacle in the Ismailia quarter of Cairo.

The Khedive has conferred the Medjidieh of the 4th class on M. Fashik Zakian, merchant of Alexandria. A Turkish lady, the daughter of Ratib Pacha, the Vali of the Hadjaz, recently determined to remain in Egypt instead of going to join her father in Arabia,and rumour has it that she wanted to start a newspaper. Hearing that her husband was owning from Constantinople to Egypt she departed, it is said, a few days ago for Paris. She is married to Hilmi Bey, a well-known Turk and an A.D.C. to the Sultan.

The following passengers left for Upper Egypt by the train de luxe on Thursday:- Mr. Rodeck, Mrs. Lindemann, Mr. Laiton, Mr. Rabtonf, Mr. Lucan, Mr. C. Wall and family, Mrs. Linderman and party, Mr. Lanvar, Mr. and Mrs. M. Obey's party, Mr. Barton, Mr. Anthony, Mr. and Mrs. Bernard, Mr. and Mme Blaske, Mr. Carton de Wiart and party, Tallat Bey, Mr. Morgan, Tallat Bey Harb, Mr. Abdel-Kerim, Denrech Bey, Mr. Hunt, Mr. and Miss Morison, Miss Johannot, Mr. Scott and friend, Mr. Bennett, Major Stainstrett, Mr. James Hains, Mr. Lewis, Mr. Garozzo and family, Mr. Wallace.

div.head:
FRENCH SEPARATION LAW.
EXTRAORDINARY SCENES.
HEATED DEBATE IN THE CHAMBER.

div.p: Of those arrested at Sainte Clothilde 17 have been detained, including Counte Rochefoucauly and Georges de Bourbon, who are charged with assaulting the polios. An interpellation on the affair in the Chamber led to a heated debate, and violent altercations. The sitting was suspended on account of the uproar. Confidence was finally voted by 384 to 166. (Reuter)

The authorities expect further scenes of violence. The Catholic youth are determined to oppose the taking of inventories, while counter demonstrations are being organised. During the afternoon the most serious disorders have taken place in the Parish Church of Saint Pierre near the Chamber. A crowd of 3,000 inside the church barricaded the doors and flung stones. The firemen climbed up to the roof and turned on the hose while the troops stormed the doors. Finally the greater part of the crowd was expelled, many persons being drenched and bleeding. An enormous and excited crowd gathered outside and engaged in incessant scuffles and affrays with the gendarmes, who repeated'y charged with drawn swords. Several persons were wounded. (Reuter)
Disorders took place at the Gros Caillon church. The firemen inundated the resisters. Several people were injured and fifty arrests were made. (Havas)

div.head:
ACCIDENT TO LADY GREY.
THROWN OUT OF HER CARRIAGE.

div.p: Lady Grey, wife of Sir E. Grey, was thrown out of her carriage yesterday and is still unconscious. (Reuter)
Lady Grey is suffering from concussion of the brain. Her state is very serious, but not hopeless. (Reuter)
The Chamber has rejected a vote of confidence in the Government by 221 to 188. (R.)
The Cabinet has resigned. (Reuter)
The Cabinet has resigned. (Havas)
The Sylvia was laden with troops. Ten were killed and seven injured. The troops were landed on the ice at Cape Novosilisky. (Reuter)
Lord Masham is dead. (Reuter)

div.head: LA DOGARESSA.
Music by Nicola Sinadino. — Words by Victor Sikano.
div.p: This opera has been admirably criticised by the "Journal du Caire" for Wednesday last. We agree more especially with what the critic has said on the influences traceable through the work—Wagner, in Tristan, Schumann, and a touch of Massenet, as well as of modern Italy. These influences are suggested, not reproduced, the composer has his own personality, very quiet and subdued, but none the less distinct, throughout. The prominent impression is great self- . restraint : the opera is a foundation, as it were, well laid, and does not lapse into tunes or brazen marches. One can instantly see that the composer has put failure far from him. This very restraint, however, renders criticism difficult. We cannot merely catalogue themes and subjects, or instrumentation, but let us touch on some of the features of the work. This may give the key to it. In the first act is a chorus the subject commencing on a single note—solo—instantly taken up by the other voices, returning again to that same commencement—a curious and effective passage. The quartette in the same act is also noticeable ; but the four voices were not evenly matched, and full justice was not done. In the second act the approach of the 'Bucentaur' marks the point of interest. We have a fugal movement, delicate and charming, and with a certain suggestive depth. This continues into a passage of trumpets ; and then follows the dance music, plaintive and solitary, recalling at once the two shepherd's Bongs in Tristan. At the end of this act occurs the Italian touch, suitable, naturally enough, to the moonlight and the waters, etc., etc. But it is only momentary ; and the third act returns again to the real scheme of the whole opera. But here it is more subtle, more flowing, full of limits and touches of mystery, those very touches that an Italian night has : flowers, perfume, the caress of the moonlight on the canal, under an infinite depth of sky, — and two lovers. And this is perhaps the key to the act and even to the opera. Here is the composer's subject. An Italian love story, renaissance in aspect, we could say even modern, and therefore finite—a love story in a land where love is of every passing d*y and night Contrast Tristan : a hero when the world of the West was still young, and fall of strange powers : love comes upon Tristan and Isolde as that force which is above dreams, or death or life itself ; their story is full of the greatness, and sorrowful mystery. of the winds and the sea and all things eternal in a wild and unknown land. We cannot now say what this opera, La Dogaressa, may or may not mean for the future. Will the composer attempt,the greater idea of the world, legends and symbols or will he describe? We have the commencement of a descriptive school, for example Strauss. and in opera Charpentier. And modernity described need not mean the end of all things. Charpentiar attempts. Paris and Montmartre, he town calling to the citadel at night Not one can say that the descriptive school may not be as great as any we have known. We pass on to the rendering of the opera and attack the defects at once, and briefly. The chorus was "reedy," as in Sansone e Dahla. Signor Palet was unsatisfactory. Whatever promise may be in his voice, it has at present little enough colour, and no form ; and he does not produce it—it never "carries." Signor Constantino was disappointing and not sufficiently audible. The "symbolic" dance before the Doge was trying; why that eternal 1830 pirouette? And what a contrast to the other flower dance! There was the realty of dancing, the unending symbol of pursuit and coy retreat, inviting pursuit we could call it "La Desiruse." Signor Zuccani, for the orchestra, is always good ; he knows his score, and uses his violins perfectly, but there are glimpses of cold-blooded cynoisism in the brass : he does not spare or humour his voices. We recall the finale of Tristan last year, and Mefistofele in both of which be might have sacrificed just a little of the climax ; it is not as if he were conducting in some opera-house where the singers would all be capable of meeting the demands of the music. Signora Bellincioni and Signor Pasquale were both admirable and displayed to the foil all that the others lacked — except Signora Zeppelli: her part is of course a second role, but her voice is sweet and tree, and well delivered. It fell to her to give the high note to the chorus in the first set, and each time she achieved the effect exactly. The scenery, dresses, and all arrangements were most excellent.

div.head: SANSONE E DALILA
div.p: This opera, given on Monday night, showed the company in a far better light then usual. Signora Savin had unexpected tone and sweet-

ness for her type of voice, usually powerful but unattractive. Signori Pasquale and Longobardi were most effective, and Signor Constantino was very pleasing. Indeed, except for the "reediness" of the sopranos in the chorus, all was excellent, unexpectedly so. The music is a delight throughout for its strength and variety : perhaps the most fascinating part is the fugal movement in the 3rd act. One suspects a canon, it is a canon, and then diverges into a fugue and prolongs what might only be technically interesting into a most dominating and profound sequence exactly fitting to the scene. The early Victorian pirouetting in the dances would lead a frivolous critic to say that these Philistines were modern Philistines in our sense of the word : and we must confess that it was at best out of place and annoying. But the opera as a whole, and we repeat, the way in which it was gives, amply compensated for these minor and temporary disadvantages.

div.head: SIGNOR SERATO'S CONCERT.
div.p: Signor Arrigo Serato gave his second concert at the Savoy Hotel on Wednesday evening before a very numerous and exceedingly appreciative audience. He was accompanied by both Mme Malatesta, the talented pianiste who played at his first concert and also by the orchestra so ably conducted by Mr. Bracale. Signor Serato is no stranger to Cairo, but his reputation grows greater every time be appears before the public. His technique is so far above the average and his brilliancy of execution and refinement of feeling rank him high among his fellow-violinists. The first item on the programme was Beethoven's magnificent concert for violin and orchestra op. 61, and Signor Serato's treatment of it was masterly in the extreme- more especially in the rondo allegro with its wonderful long drawn-out solo. The second item was Liszts' 'Fantaisie Hongroise," arranged for the piano and orchestra, and Mme. Malatesta surpassed herself in her rendering of the same. Her touch is wonderful, especially for a woman, and her execution is equally fine. She also possesses the happy faculty, not always found in a pianiste, of being a particularly sympathetic accompanist. The final event on the programme was Vieuxtemps' "Adagio religioso" and though Vieuxtemps' works are slight and may be thin after Beethoven's and Liszts' they are full of grace and tuneful melody Signor Serato met with a great ovation and his playing evoked a great display of honest enthusiasm. He is assuredly a remarkably fine violinist and it is sincerely hoped that he will give Cairo many more opportunities of hearing him again. Congratulations are also due to Mme Malatesta and to the orchestra, to which not a little of Wednesday's success was due. Its performance was most excellent both in tone, time, and appreciation of the ensemble.

div.head: EGYPTIAN CIGARETTES.
THE NEW GERMAN CUSTOMS TAX.
div.p: The scheme of the German Government to increase the taxes on imported Oriental tobacco and cigarettes has raised considerable trepidation among the many persons interested in the Egyptian cigarette trade as Germany is Egypt's best client as regards cigarettes. div.head: BOOKS OF REFERENCE.
div.p: "Who's Who," the issue for 1906 of which we have received, increases in bulk with each succeeding issue, and the extent of its usefulness as a guide to the life and works of men and women whose position or rank entitles them to a place in its pages, increases in proportion. "Who's Who" (London : A & C. Black) is a distinctly valuable addition to one's reference library, and should be on the desk of every man of the world. The "Who's Who Year Book" (London : A. & C Black) is made up of the tables which were formerly such a popular feature in "Who's Who" itself. These tables were, in fact, the original nucleus of the took, which developed on different lines into a biographical anneal. The information it of necessity brief, but pertinent, and it is one of the must universally useful little directories as yet produced. "The Writers and Artists' Year Book" contains in compact form about 600 addresses to which MSS may be sent, with the names of the editors in some cases, a general idea of the stories and articles wanted, and other information to guide those who wish to place their literary work. The book also caters for all artists who can do good work with pen or brush, and who seek acceptance in magazines. The publishers are Messrs. A. & C. Black.

div.head: ROMANCE IN A BOOTH
div.p: A love romance that is probably without equal is reported to have taken place at one of the booths during the fair at Geneva. In this booth, the "Newcastle Chronicle" says, was exhibited a girl of 18, armless and legless, but of exceedingly fine features. Her show name is "Princess Annette." A young German who had gone to stars, remained to admire the pretty face, and after numerous visits became so enamoured of it as to forget the other physical defects. When the question of marriage was mooted, the showman strenuously resisted the loss of his loading "draw," and the young German laid information against him for exercising duress. That, however, was a slow process, so watching his opportunity, and armed with the necessary licences. Romeo carried off his Juliet bodily to church, where they were at once married, the bridegroom holding the bride in his arms during the ceremony.

div.head: PIGMIES' QUAINT WEDDING.
div.p: Two of the pigmies from the Ituri Forest, Central Africa, are spending their honeymoon at Brandesburton Hall, a manor house about 20 miles from Hull. When the bride, Kurake, the beauty of the party, brought over by Mr. James Harrison, and Matuka, her lover, had made up their minds to be united, they went to their chief, and said, "Bokane, we are going to be married." After a little opposition the wedding was agreed to, and the bride and bridegroom solemnly brought forward all their real and personal estate, consisting of beads, knives, razors, and bracelets, and mingled the two lots together in one basket. Matuka then sealed the compact with a kiss, and there ensued much dusky rejoicing.
